E. Operating Procedures
Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered process that address primary operations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practice and manufacturers. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current accurate by management. The procedures are maintained current and accurate revising them as necessary by employee's suggestion, compliance audit, PHAs, Good Engineering practice, Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and implemented through Management of Change.
Covered Process Operating procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task and maintain the covered process unit operating within its safe limits.

H. Incident Investigation
Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC will promptly investigates all incidents related to a covered process that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personal injury. The goal of each investigation will be to determine the facts and develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team will document its findings, develops recommendations to prevent future occurrences, and forward these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations will be tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation will be documented and investigation reports will be retained for at least 5 years.
I. Compliance Audits

At least every 3 years a Compliance Audit addressing OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineering Practices are conducted by employees and management of Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC. This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed. Final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

Executive Summary - Live Oak Terminal
ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC owns and operates the Live Oak Terminal, in Live Oak County, Texas.   It is a natural gas liquids stabilizer plant with associated unloading/loading and storage terminal. The stabilizer skid includes stripper and debutanizer towers to separate the pressurized liquids into rich gas overhead, NGL product, and stabilized condensate.
Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC has a commitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.
DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Live Oak Terminal is located near Three Rivers, Texas and operates a variety of processes to produce the following petroleum products:
1.	Propane
2.	NGLs
3.	Condensate
These substances can contain the following regulated chemicals:
a.	Methane
b.	Ethane
c.	Propane
d.	Isobutane
e.	Butane
f.	Isopentane
g.	Pentane

A. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Live Oak Terminal has had no RMP regulated substance release during the past five years. 
GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
B. Employee Participation/Document Management System
Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention as follows:
1. Updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information
2. Performing necessary calculations for PSM and RMP
3. Maintaining good engineering practices
4. Particip

ating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team
Employees have access to all information pertaining to the accident prevention program.
C. Process Safety Information
Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These technical documents address the following:
1. Chemical properties and associated hazards
2. Necessary Block Flow Diagrams of the process
3. Maximum intended inventories
4. Upper and Lower limits of process fixed and rotating equipment
5. Equipment design basis and configuration information
6. Identification of all necessary Regulatory equipment design documents
7. Sufficient information to assure good engineering practices
The location of the technical documents referenced above is listed in the Process Safety Information portion of the PSM.
Chemical specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in safety data sheet (SDS). For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperatures, level and composition in the operator procedures manual. The facility maintains the process within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems.
The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings. This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to safety features in the process are not compromised.

G. Mechanical Integrity

Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC has established practices and procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating and emergency shutdown equipment. The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:

1. Conducting training
2. Developing written procedures
3. Performing inspections and tests
4. Correcting identified deficiencies
5. Applying quality assurance measures

In combination, these activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process. Maintenance personnel receive training on:

1. Overview of the process
2. Safety and Health hazards
3. Applicable maintenance procedures
4. Emergency response plan
5. Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.

Written procedures provide that work is performed in a consistent manner and serve as a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help verify that equipment functions as intended and that equipment is within acceptable limits. If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service. In addition, Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC Management will evaluate the contractor safety program and performance during the selection of a contractor. Facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance with regard to their safety obligations.
M. Safe Work Practices
Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC has standing safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, EPA, Industrial Standards and Good Engineering Practice in place to help provide employee, public and process safety.
N. Specialized Safety Features
Site specific detection and control equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the plant to:
1. Contain/control a release
2. Quickly detect a release, and
3. Reduce the consequences of an RMP-regulated substance release
The following type of safety features are used in the covered process:
Release Detection
1. Hydrocarbon and hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms, where applicable.
Release Containment/Control
1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
2. Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process
3. Automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and automatically operate
all automatic valves to their fail-safe position, diverting all incoming gas to the emergency flare.
4. Curbing or diking to contain liquids releases
5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation
6. Atmospheric relief devices
Release Mitigation
1. Fire suppression and extinguishing system
2. Trained emergency response personnel
3. Personal protective equipment
4. Blast-resistant building to help protect control systems and personnel
O. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

1. Determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards
2. Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the proposed change
Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are trained on the changes.
K. Pre-Startup Safety Review
Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC conducts a PSSR for any new facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to see that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and services as quality assurance verification that the accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.
L. Contractors
Maverick Terminals Three Rivers, LLC uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near Covered Process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:
1. Perform their work in a safe manner
2. Have the appropriate knowledge and skills
3. Are aware of the hazards in their workplace
4. Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency
5. Understand and follow site safety rules
6. Inform facility personnel of any hazard that they find during their work
